title: Riot will have to nerf Kalista pretty creatively IMO.
body:
Her kit works well as it is, but then there's overbearing parts of abilities that probably need to be addressed.

**What I Expect Riot to change (Something along the lines of these.):**

1. Put a damage cap on her Rend vs. Monsters for the sake of Dragon's and Barons getting nuked for 1k+ HP.
2. Remove/Reduce Mana Return on Rend.
3. Remove/Reduce Application of Rend stacks on multiple targets via Runaan's Hurricane. E.g. Kalista AA = 1 Stack, Runaan's Hurricane Bolt = 1/2 Stack. This would slow her wave clear but still keep it relatively intact. It would also put more emphasis on Kalista focusing targets rather than just spamming auto attacks and Rend'ing anyone that's marked.

EDIT: 4. Reduce Kalista's Attack Speed per level by ~0.5.

replies.body:
What we're currently looking is reducing the amount her attack wind ups get faster when she gets attack speed.

When champions get attack speed they both make more attacks per second and each individual attack takes less time to perform. In Kalista's case that means she's spending less time in her attack windup and so she gets to dash more often/doesn't spend as much time preparing to dash. Attack speed's making her more mobile than we think's appropriate, so we're going to adjust that.

As per usual we'll then see what sort of spot she lands in after that change, assess whether other changes are appropriate too or not.

Why are you working on that when her E is invalidating smite at all points of the game?

This is the reason the game is so poorly balanced. You guys blatantly ignore incredibly pressing issues (You remember the Lucian rework? Kassadin in S3?) and instead try to make the most asinine changes in the world (Ahri's massive buffs to areas that weren't affected by DFG, making Nidalee the new Lee Sin.)

Stop messing around, and deal with the problem.

We're confident that the amount of extra mobility Kalista gets from attack speed is a problem, so we're addressing that, given how effective she can be against some melee champions especially. Regardless of what changes it might or might not be appropriate to make to her E we believe this change is a good one. 

As far as her E and Smite go creating an ADC with really strong objective control if she can spend a decent chunk of time attacking a target was something we wanted to try out with Kalista. Various other ADCs are great for objective control too, they do it by helping you kill baron or dragon really fast though (think Vayne or Kog for example). We wanted to offer objective strength in a different way and Kalista's certainly doing that. Whether she's too effective in that role, in terms of forcing the enemy to deal with her rather than trying for a last minute steal, is a great question. It's certainly possible her E might need to be capped against monsters, we're not sure if that's the appropriate call at this point though and would like to avoid homogenizing champions if there are healthy ways to avoid doing so.

I'm not sure if this has been addressed in detail before, but since we're talking about dangers of homogenizing, I'm curious what you guys think Kalista's identity is really supposed to be? 

She has her passive which adds a very different form of mobility and a unique power in this aspect than no other champion has access to.
She has her Oathsworn which to some degree gives her a dependency on her partner. I'd personally say this really feels like an auxiliary piece of the champion with how much her power is notable in other places.
She has a good deal of strong Crowd Control available in her kit compared to most ranged AD.
She has reasonable kiting range and power.
She also feels like a really strong duelist who will ramp up into a kill if allowed an extended trade.

I feel like this last point is actually supposed to be the strongest identity point of the champion, but it really feels like it is in contest with the other pieces of the puzzle that make up Kalista. Do you think her identity is as focused as it needs to be right now? Are you okay with where other AD carries who might be picked for their strong team supporting abilities are in relation to her? 

I'm mostly just curious. I don't have a real vested interest in either nerfing or keeping the champion where she is since I haven't really been committing myself to League so much at the present time, but there do seem to be some compelling concerns for her place in the roster and it's always interesting to revisit where the balancing point of the ranged dps class as a whole swings at any given time as the game changes and philosophies shift.

This really strikes at the problem with Kalista - she doesn't have a single, solid identity.  She is basically two champions mashed together.

Her entire theme is about vengeance in cooperation with her Oathsworn.  The unique part of her kit is binding the Oathsworn.  She is a utility / cooperation carry, with high stacking damage.  There is enough there to make her a unique and interesting champion.

But then, she has her hopping passive randomly tacked on.  It doesn't fit into her kit at all, nor does it fit her thematically. What is revenge-oriented about being able to hop around like a kangaroo, to kite and attack enemies with impunity?

The embodiment of revenge should be about hunting down enemies, chasing them down or laying traps for them.  Imagine something like the Terminator - cannot be reasoned with, cannot be stopped, will inescapably come for you in the end, but you can maybe outrun it for a while.  That is what Kalista should be like, not a ghost on a pogo stick.

This is entirely a shot in the dark, but I think Kalista's passive comes from the idea that as a Spirit of Vengence, she can go anywhere she needs to go. If her preferred mode of transportation is hopping around like a bunny given sugar, that's her life choice. I can see why they'd leave it out of her legends though.

In horror films, you run away from the evil that's chasing you, race away until you've left it far behind, finally find a place that looks safe, lock the door behind you... and then you find your pursuer already there and waiting for you.

Now imagine every time something like this happens, that the antagonist got there by hopping on a pogo stick.

More seriously, though, you expect a spirit to move great distances when you're not looking at it, or to slip into the shadows and appear somewhere else - something more like Katarina's Shunpo instead of this constant hopping.

I don't know man, if I saw someone chasing after me on a pogo stick, I'd be pretty damn terrified. You know how hard it is to ride one of those? If he manages to catch up to me, thats a feat in itself.
that's basically cottontail teemo.

Don't take this the wrong way but... Do you actually play your own game? 

I'm not trying to be a dick, and I totally understand the idea of "making Kalista a strong in objective control" is an interesting path for a character... BUT, here's what makes me wonder if you even play the game: Do you understand why every other such ability is capped against monsters? Or why Smite has always been a thing in the jungle even back when you didn't necessarily need it to survive and clear? Why Smite would still be a jungle auto-lock even if you removed all the little Smite-bonuses many jungle mobs have? 

Because of objective securing. Because of how important that is.

Because, up until Kalista came around, Smite did the most damage to any jungle objective, and thus was a way to guarantee them barring player error. It was the reason Junglers were important and had presence late game and why killing a jungler generally results in really high jungle pressure. 

Enter Kalista. Kalista makes an objective "unsmiteable", uncontestable. Once Kalista starts an objective Smite is literally no longer a threat as Kalista can simply outdamage it. 

You think this is healthy for the game in any way, shape, or form? Kalista starts an objective and the only possible threat you can level against the team is a full team wipe. If you can't threaten that it's a completely free objective even if their jungler is dead, or securing something else. 

Now, you could also "unlock" similar skills in different characters, like Cho'Gath, but the ability to secure objectives is so crucial to high level play that I guarantee you, with no shadow of a doubt, that as long as a character has such an ability and isn't completely terrible/unusuable outright, they will be a top pick/ban. Which is the beauty of having Smite be the highest damage, "objective secure", utility - any character can use it.  

Same is going to happen to Kalista. As long as she has the 100% guaranteed objective secure she is going to remain a top pick/ban unless (or until) you nerf her into the ground. 

I get that you want more diversity, but there is good and bad "diversity", good and bad "homogenization". A character that would have an easy to hit, 3 second cooldown, 100% guaranteed kill, targeted spell with no mana cost would be pretty unique. Also pretty broken. Which is what Kalista is right now - Broken. Regardless of her overall power one facet of what she does breaks the game. That's not healthy in any way, shape, or form I can possibly imagine.

I feel that there are certain changes that Riot is too hasty (especially when it comes to new champs; 'Azir is underperforming, clearly it's because he's weak and not because he's new  and has a bunch of bugs' anyone?), but I also feel that there are some changes that Riot has said 'we agree this is a problem' but then either put it on the backburner or spend so much time looking for a perfect solution that it appears they put it on the backburner. (the fighter rework, lee sin, etc.)

That's honestly one of my biggest complaints about balance right now; it just feels really uneven.

How about removing that disgusting hop as well? She's a ghost, not a kangaroo...  An easy place to start is by taking out the most toxic part of her kit and replacing it with the percent damage on her W.

Can I express a wish or something like that regarding Kalista's E ? Right now, I have a hard time to appropriately time the activation of E during teamfights to finish off enemies with the E. I know, in theory I could just count the times I've thrown spears at particular enemies, but in general I have a thousand other things that need my attention. In practice, I end up pressing way too early, or not at all.

So, I was thinking: If Zed has a "marker" hovering over the target of his ultimate ability when he already dealt enough damage to kill it, would it be possible to somehow signal the point when Kalista has stacked enough spears in a target to finish it off?

The potential benefit I see here is a) clarity for the Kalista player, and possibly b) clarity for the targeted player. You could make it visible to everyone, so basically the guy knows when to back out of a fight.

If this actually makes her too strong, I'd be even fine if she only has this extra information for a brief duration immediately after she activated her ultimate.

tl:dr : counting during intense teamfights is serious business, and I screw up too often and it keeps frustrating me : can I please have an indicator for the "optimal" finish-off use case? Please?

Definitely not about Kalista, but you mention securing Dragons/Barons as a unique thing you think is interesting, so I wanted to bring up an old ability interaction that was taken away and your opinion on it.

So Trundle, pre change, could use his ultimate on Dragon and Baron.  This allowed him to be fantastic at securing objectives for his team, as the targets were weaker and he could tank very well.  After his changes, that was taken away from him.  

Do you believe that it would not be healthy for him to regain that unique feature to his kit?  In all fairness, we don't really have a jungle/bruiser outside of Nunu that specializes in securing objectives.  And Nunu's is more about the burst at the end, not the quick takedown during.  Just wanted to see if you thought that might help Trundle out a bit in an objective-heavy meta.

While I definitely think that the unlimited stacking E is a cool thing, and that it does bring a unique form of objective control, I question why you would put this on Kalista's kit specifically. She already has two identities, the teamwork-ADC and the super-kiter, so the objective control thing seems really tacked on. 

Why put it on Kalista instead of say, putting it on Twitch, a ADC already known to jungle? It would give him better clearing after the way jungle leashing changes hurt him, and it would provide him a unique way to scale into lategame instead of just relying on cheesy level 2-3 ganks to snowball. Or why not put in on another champion entirely, perhaps an ADC *designed* for the jungle?

While it may seem like its too late to get rid of it, I don't think it is. It would be very easy to give Kalista's E a stack limit and balance accordingly. Perhaps the stack limit could increase based on an enemy champion's maximum health, giving Kalista a way to deal with health stackers since the cap isn't unlimited anymore.
So you don't think her rend over shadows the idea of smite? If a Kalista is attacking baron does it basically mean there is no chance (counter play) for a baron steal?
You could 1. Kill her 2. Contest dragon/baron so that Kalista can't over smite it

Lets be fair, If she's attacking baron, she's not attacking your team. Surely you can capitalize on the fact that their ADC isn't doing any damage and go for a fight? I haven't played Kalista before, does her rend stack on multiple targets simultaneously? Because if it does, you could make rend only stack on EITHER a minion/monster or a champion(s). That way she can't take baron whilst killing your entire team. Idk.

It does stack on multiple targets. That might be a good change to alleviate some excess power, but on the other hand it does also add another level of clarity problems to a champion whose damage is already hard to read. Certainly wouldn't be a quick fix to be implemented either. Thematically, I think it would be better if the ability only stacked on one target at a time. That would hurt Kalista's waveclear quite a bit...but I think she doesn't really need to have that as a strong point.

One thing to also keep in mind is that it may still be problematic for a champion to have too many options compared to other champions. People (who have a reasonable understanding of the game) don't complain as much about Lee because he is numerically OP, for example, but because he is so incredibly versatile.

One of the big questions about Kalista's balance is whether she threatens to entirely push more team dependent play-making carries like Ashe or Varus (and perhaps Ezreal) out of their already small niche in the game. If Riot wants to emphasize Kalista in the direction of a very objective focused champion, though, it would certainly be better if it was more of a pressing decision when it came down to those moments.

I think that when you guys make some champions you are looking at a small pool of potential counters for the champion but not seeing how the champion just strictly outclasses some others. When I look at champions I look at these 6 categories to decide how strong a champion is- 
-Utility (Vision, Shields, Disengage, Ally Control, etc.) Notable Champions- Thresh, Orianna, Galio
-Mobility (Ability to move around the map through resets, abilities, etc.) Notable Champions- Ahri, Kassadin, Udyr
-Damage (Ability to reliably build hybrid damage or do massive amounts of damage, DPS) Notable Champions- Yasuo, Irelia, Syndra
-Hard CC (Ability to lockdown dangerous/priority targets, the easier to provide the better) Notable Champions- Sejuani, Lissandra, Rek'sai
-Range (Ability to provide damage at a safe distance) Notable Champions- Nidalee, Caitlyn, Xerath
-Sustain (Ability to shrug off damage, stay in game without recalling, Self Shield) Notable Champions- Warwick, Garen, Trundle
Kalista has all 6 of these categories, 4 of which are strengthen to a good amount through items.

ON A LESS SERIOUS NOTE #BUFFVARUSTOOPSTATUSNEXT2015

I'm not sure how that would make a difference. She will still hop a set distance at a set rate based on boot tier and AS. In order for her entire windup animation to occur within a shorter period, you have to speed it up. So how exactly do you slow down her windup without reducing AS?

The only way I can interpret this is that you want to put a hidden AS cap on Kalista. This would essentially be admitting that her Martial Poise passive is completely broken and should be removed from the game.
